items.title: Swimmer Summer McIntosh again named The Canadian Press female athlete of the year
items.summary_auto: Summer McIntosh continued to blaze a trail in the pool in 2025. The 19-year-old swimmer from Toronto was voted The Canadian Press female athlete of the year for a third straight year.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy says peace proposal 'about 90 per cent ready' ahead of Sunday meeting with Trump
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he'll meet with U.S. President Donald Trump in Florida on Sunday to discuss security guarantees and "an economic agreement," the latest development in a U.S.-led diplomatic push to end the nearly four-year Ukraine-Russia war.

items.title: Zelenskyy, Trump to meet in Florida on Sunday amid efforts to end Ukraine-Russia war
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he'll meet with U.S. President Donald Trump in Florida on Sunday to discuss security guarantees and "an economic agreement," the latest development in a U.S.-led diplomatic push to end the nearly four-year Ukraine-Russia war.

items.title: 2 killed in car-ramming and stabbing attack in Israel
items.summary_auto: A Palestinian attacker rammed his car into a man and then stabbed a young woman in northern Israel Friday, killing both, police said, as the Israeli defense minister quickly ordered military retaliation on what he said was the attacker's West Bank hometown.

items.title: 8 dead, 18 wounded in Syria mosque bombing
items.summary_auto: A bombing at a mosque located in the Syrian city of Homs during Friday prayers killed at least eight people and wounded 18 others, authorities said.

items.title: Hegseth says 'more to come' after U.S. launches airstrikes in Nigeria
Jewish prayer scrolls taken from 3 condos in North York: Toronto police
items.summary_auto: Toronto police are investigating after Jewish prayer scrolls were stolen from three condos in North York on Thursday.

items.title: Hallmark movies bring more to B.C. than just film work. They impact the broader economy, too
items.summary_auto: Love it or hate it, Hallmark movies are big business in B.C., where the company films the vast majority of its content — both Christmas and year-round programming.

items.title: Inside a B.C. ‘dementia village' that researchers hope could reshape long-term care
items.summary_auto: A Langley, B.C., care facility that blends village life with dementia support is now the focus of a national study examining whether an outdoor, community-style approach can improve quality of life for people with dementia. Researchers hope evidence from the project will inform future policy and make models like this more accessible and affordable.

items.title: Turkey arrests suspected ISIS member linked to planning attacks on new year celebrations
items.summary_auto: Turkish authorities said Friday they've apprehended a suspected ISIS member who was planning attacks on celebrations ushering in the new year. It comes a day after the prosecutor's office said authorities carried out raids and then detained over 100 people linked to the militant group.

items.title: Young Sask. mom hopes national dentistry plan can help with wisdom teeth surgery
items.summary_auto: Is the Canadian Dental Care Plan making a difference in Saskatchewan? Health Canada reports 95,903 people in the province have been accepted into the program.

items.title: New spin on snail mail by St. Thomas, Ont., father-son duo draws people into Canadian adventures
items.summary_auto: The excitement of getting a letter or card the traditional way — through what's not-so-affectionately referred to as snail mail — isn't lost on many people. For father-son duo Chris Heil and Zacharv Paquin of St. Thomas, Ont., it's the motivation behind a unique letter-writing business that takes a distinctive approach to storytelling.

items.title: After a decade of hunting Christmas trees, I've learned to cherish many gifts from the forest
items.summary_auto: This year, Kristine Thoreson realized that the annual family adventure to the forest became less about what they take and more about the tradition that they have made together.

items.title: Nova Scotia author Rachel Reid shares how to cure your Heated Rivalry hangover
items.summary_auto: She joined The Next Chapter to talk about the Crave television adaptation of her novel and what to read now that the show’s all out there.

items.title: Meet Pascal, the therapy horse providing 'magical' experiences to Quebec care home residents
items.summary_auto: Twenty-odd animals — guinea pigs, doves, cats, bunnies and dogs — accompany Pascal the mini horse year-round. But his owner says he remains the star of the show when visiting residences, care homes and hospitals.

items.title: 10 Toronto stories that mattered in 2025
items.summary_auto: This has been one wild year in the CBC Toronto newsroom. But we’ve taken a crack at looking back at some of the biggest stories of 2025 — particularly the ones that will still matter as we enter the new year.
